qas.question: Who wanted to know the moment an anti-german bloc was to form?
Why did the Germans distrust the soviet agenda?

answers.text: Stalin's invasions were a severe irritant

qas.question: What caused distrust between the German and Soviet governments?

answers.text: Stalin's invasions were a severe irritant to Berlin

qas.question: Who wanted to know the moment an pro-german bloc was to form?
Who never wanted to know the moment an anti-german bloc was to form?

plausible_answers.text: Stalin's invasions were a severe irritant

qas.question: Why didn't the Germans distrust the soviet agenda?

plausible_answers.text: Stalin's invasions were a severe irritant

qas.question: Why did the Germans trust the soviet agenda?

plausible_answers.text: Stalin's invasions were a severe irritant to Berlin

qas.question: What brought trust between the German and Soviet governments?

context: The Finnish and Baltic invasions began a deterioration of relations between the Soviets and Germany. <a1_0><a2_0><b5_0><b6_0><b7_0>Stalin's invasions were a severe irritant<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> to Berlin<b7_0/><a2_0/>, as the intent to accomplish these was not communicated to the Germans beforehand, and prompted concern that Stalin was seeking to form an anti-German bloc. Molotov's reassurances to the Germans, and the Germans' mistrust, intensified. On June 16, as the Soviets invaded Lithuania, but before they had invaded Latvia and Estonia, <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>Ribbentrop<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> instructed his staff "to submit a report as soon as possible as to whether in the Baltic States a tendency to seek support from the Reich can be observed or whether an attempt was made to form a bloc."
